Hopkins Vs.PaintersIn Game Tomorrow
By DAVE BAKER
Copy Editor
Over one thousand Hopkins alumni and about ten University
of Maryland lacrosse players will arrive tumultuously on campus
today and tomorrow as the annual Hopkins Alumni Homecoming
Weekend gets under way.
The first group will take part in a series of luncheons, banquets, class reunions and discussion groups; the Maryland contingent will meet with the Jay lacrossemen which could decide
the National Lacrosse Championship.
Activities begin tonight, according to Mr. Osmar P. Steinwald,
Director of Alumni Relations, with the Johns Hopkins Engineers'
annual dinner and assembly beginning at 6 p.m. in the Aeronautics
Building. Guest Speaker Dr. John Strong will deliver an address
on "Getting Ready for Mars." Also, the Classes of 1918 and 1933
will hold reunion dinners this evening.
The traditional Blue Jay, beer, music and cheers will spark
a pep rally at 7 this evening in front of the Old Dorm. Students
are encouraged, says an announcement, to come and "make your
own pep speeches." The lacrosse team and coaches will also be
present.
Saturday's scheduled events are headed by a tour of the
campus in the morning to acquaint visiting alumni with recent
facelifting at Homewood.
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, Hopkins University President, is to
chair the second annual symposium feating seven faculty members,
from 10:30 to 12 noon Saturday in Shriver Hall. This year's topic
is "An Intimate Report on New Developments at Johns Hopkins."
Dr. Donald H. Andrews, Provost P. Stewart Macaulay, Dr. William
D. McElroy, Dean Richard A. Mumma, Dean Robert H. Roy, Dean
Thomas B. Turner, and 41)r. John Walton will participate.
A buffet luncheon at noon tomorrow for the alumni will feaJOHN JORY

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 16, 1958

Long Saturates TV Game, Parade, Dance, Drinks
With Political Ads Spark Homecoming Weekend
(Continued from Page 1)
In an attempt to curry the
favor of as many Maryland Democrats as possible before the
Primary election date, Tuesday,
May 20, Dr. Clarence D. Long
launched a saturation campaign
of the various television stations
in Maryland.
This TV campaign began about
two weeks ago and will reach its
climax on Monday, the day before the. primary, when Dr. Long
will have six brief filmed messages transmitted via Baltimore
television channels. In addition
to this Monday splurge, the Hopkins economics professor will be
seen four times today and tomorrow and will make two appearances on Sunday.
Dr. Long also appears daily on
a one minute spot over the Salisbury, Maryland, UHF channel.
These spot telecasts are composed of filmed sequences of
Dr. Long meeting the voters in
a drug store and in the Mondawmin Shopping Center.
Commenting upon the statement of Dean Acheson, former
U. S. Secretary of State, that
Maryland needs a "responsible
boss", Dr. Long said, "The remedy for the problems of democracy can be found through democracy. What is wrong with
Maryland politics is 'bossism' in
any way. This can be seen in
the counties which are devoid

DR. CLARENCE D. LONG

Varsity Lacrosse Team Set
For Journey To England
By JOEL GORDEN
Coach Robert Scott, Trainer
James Benson and a squad of
twenty-three players will leave
Baltimore June 16 for Montreal
for the first leg of their scheduled trip to England to play a
series of contests against English collegiate and club lacrosse
teams.
Visiting England at the invitation of the English Lacrosse
Union, the team will spend about
two months abroad. The first
game will be played against
Cambridge, where they will stay
two days. They will return to
Manchester July 12, where they
will play a series of tilts against
club teams.
From July 12-16 the squad
will take a break. They will take
a sight-seeing tour of Scotland.
On the 21st the Jays will return
to England to play Kenton Lacrosse Club. As a follow-up the
stickmen will meet the South of
England All-Star Lacrosse Club.

"The Class of 1958 will present
the third edition of its "Jazz at
Homewood" series in cooperation with the other undergraduate classes, this Sunday, May
18. It will be held on the Keyser
Quadrangle from 3 to 5 p.m. or
in the gym in case of rain, "announced senior class President
Oz Steinwald.
The "Spruce Street Six" from
the University of Pennsylvania
will present Dixie Land music
specially edited to the collegiate
atmosphere at the concert.
During the last three years
the Class of '58 has supported
the "Jazz at Homewood" series.
The last two years the Class has
chosen "Eli's Chosen Six" from
Yale to entertain the crowds attending. This year in an effort
to reduce expenses, a group
nearer to the school was chosen.

in which class officers will bear

Association President and the

1908 will receive their half-century medallion from Dr. Eisenhower at 1:45.
The annual Booster Clubsponsored Float Parade, under
the chairmanship of Dick Wiegmann, will begin at 2:00. At least

12 fraternities are expected to
construct floats on the theme
"Hopkins Goes to England."
Winner of the float competition
will gain possession of the
Booster Club trophy for one year
and of a smaller permanent
trophy and will have its float
queen named "Queen of Homecoming".
Regular Homecoming excitement will culminate in frenzy
at the Hopkins,.Maryland lacrosse game at 2:30 Saturday,
perhaps the decisive match of
the National Lacrosse Championship. The importance of this
meet, plus some traditional
antagonism toward our opponents, should bring a crowd of
noisy spectators to -Homewood
Field tomorrow afternoon.
Additional stands have been
ordered for the game, and
Booster Club souvenir booklets
will be sold at $1 each to raise

July 24 to August first the team
will be on its own to visit
Europe. Only a fifth of the
players will be on the Empress
of England when it sails for

of the team will remain abroad
at their own expense.
They will also see action
against the three collegiate
teams of Oxford, Cambridge and
Manchester.

Dr. Charles S. Singleton, Johns

When he first came to Johns

Returned To JHTJ
In 1948 Professor Singleton
joined,the faculty of Harvard
University as professor of Romance Languages. He returned
to Johns Hopkins last September
as professor of humanistic studies, making use of his broad
knowledge of philosophy, arts and
history of Europe during the
Middle Ages and the Renaissance.
The scholar is currently working on a three-volume commentary on Dante's Divine Comedy
which is an outgrowth of his
definitive books on Italian literature.
Born In Oklahoma
Born in McCloud, Oklahoma,
Dr. Singleton received his A.B.
degree in 1931 at the University
of Missouri and his Ph.D. in
1936 from the University of California.
From 1934 to 1936 he was an
exchange Fellow in Italy. After
his return to this country he
taught for a year each at the
University of California and the
University of Missouri.

As of now the student drive
has been "very successful", according to Drive Chairman Os
Steinwald. $5,000 is needed to
reach the student goal of $9,000.
Steinwald feels that "the drive
has functioned well. The crucial factor will be Homecoming
Weekend. We hope to make our
most money then. How well we
do at Homecoming depends on
the weather and the attendance.
The weather is the big factor."
A thirty-page Lacrosse souvenir will be sold during the
Homecoming game as part of
the drive.
The program will feature the
history of Lacrosse at Hopkins.
It will be a permanent type
booklet that could be used for
reference, and it will contain
statistics, graphs and drawings.

and Walter Herman of the Sunpapers have done the writing.

Chemical Concern
Grants Thousands
For Cancer Work
A $5,000 grant has been made
to the Division of Clinical Pharmacology of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital by the American Cyanamid Company.
The award is designed to promote the evaluation of anticancer drugs and compounds affecting the central nervous system.
Dr. Louis Lasagna of the Hopkins, in accepting the award
from Dr. Benjamin Carey, Medical Director of Lederle Laboratories of American Cyanamid,
said that the work of his group
falls into two main categories.
These are the evaluation of
drugs as sedatives, hypnotics and
tranquillizers, and the testing of
drugs for cancer chemotherapy.
The work is being conducted at
the Hopkins Hospital and at state
institutions.
The American Cyanamid grant
is part of a $1,300,000 award
program designed to spur basic
scientific and medical research.

school year from 2 p.m. to

Among the featured artists
are Cecile Baer, Jack Bonsai,
Joe Falzone, Jane Frank,

Honor
Recent trials conducted by
the Honor Commission have
involved nine students charged
with possible violations of
the Honor Code. They included one senior and eight
freshmen; by school they were
seven Arts and Sciences, and
two Engineers.
In six instances the verdict
rendered was acquittal, in
instances the verdict was
guilty. One freshman was
blacklisted and failed in the
course concerned. Two others,
also freshmen, were blacklisted.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 16, 1958

'Stormers' Join Other Schools, Hopkins GainsRecognition
Form Dramatic Commission For E. E. Honor. Society
The Johns Hopkins Electrical
Engineering Honor Society received national recognition last
Friday when it was installed as
the Gamma Upsilon Chapter of
the National Eta Kappa Nu Association.

As "a means of contacting
other dramatic groups in the
Baltimore area," the Barnstormers have joined forces with
thespian clubs from four neighboring colleges to officially form
Dramatic
Intercollegiate
an
Commission, Barnstormer President Mike Dale announced this
week.
The Commission, comprising
dramatic groups from Mt. St.
Agnes College, Villa Julie, Notre
Dame College, Loyola College,
and Hopkins, was formed at a
joint meeting last Saturday at
Villa Julie. Tentative members
in the group are Towson State
Teachers College and Goucher,
Dale explained.
Four-Fold Purpose
According to Dale, the Commission was formed following a
proposal made by Mt. St. Agnes
College's dramatic club at a
workshop last month.
Its purposes are to provide
members of the opposite sex for
roles in individual group Productions, the free exchange of
properties, costumes, and other
effects, the exchange of publicity, and the arrangement of
yearly schedules to avoid duplication of the same plays or dates.
The group's officers, elected at
last weelc's organizational meeting, are: President, Enid Sale,
and secretary, Barbara McNamara, both of Mt. St. Agnes.
Meetings Planned
The Commission will hold
meetings at least twice a year,
and will plan "social meetings

Santuski.
Also elected this year were
Goucher and Church Home
School of Nursing delegates.
From the former are Ely Moerman and Dina Erlemann; from
Church Home, Joy Davis and
Gene Wendel.

Barnstormer President Mike Dale courts Mary Waesche in a
dress rehearsal of "Charley's Aunt," the comedy which the theater
group successfully presented this spring. Dale and other Barnstormers have recently organized a Drama Association with members of theatre groups in other Maryland universities. The
Association is designed for cooperative, inter-collegiate work in the
theatre.
and theatre parties," according
to Dale. There will be membership fees, but no exchange of directors, he said.
"We feel this group will benefit every member club, especially as a joint effort to aid area
collegiate dramatics," Dale commented, adding that "one of its
main values will be the joint
publicity program among the
schools."
Dale Releases Schedule
Dale also released the schedule of Barnstormer productions
for the '58-'59 academic year.
The frosh production, to be given
October 17, will be Maxwell
Anderson's "Both Your Houses."
The regular Barnstormer plays
will be Karel Capek's "R.U.R.,"

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 16, 1958

Hopkins To Sponsor Pitt Cites Expanding Needs
Of Education In Address
Fifth-Year Training
Six Baltimore students are
among 45 chosen by The Johns
Hopkins University to take part
in a fifth-year tdacher training
program which begins in June, it
by Dr.
was announced today7
John Walton, chairman of the
Department of Education.
The students were chosen from
200 applicants representing colleges and universities throughout the nation and "comprise a
superior group," according to
University officials.
The Baltimore residents are:
Miss Judith Ann Goldberg,from
Goucher College whose field is
social studies; Anna F. Kovasznay, a graduate of Royal Hungarian Peter Pazmany University in Budapest, who will major
in languages; Joseph A. M. Lettre, Pikesville, a student at the
University of Maryland majoring in social studies; Thor S.
Ramsland, majoring in social
studies at Johns Hopkins; Robert
C. Smoot III, a science student
from The Pennsylvania State
University; and Miss Ruth Dolores Townsend, a Wilson College English major.

The Johns Hopkins Program
begins in June with the summer
session and continues through
the full academic year. Each person in the program will also be
hired by a board of education
to teach one semester in a public
or private school in the greater
Baltimore area. The second
semester is to be spent in academic work at the graduate level
on the Homewood Campus.
The program, made possible a
year ago by a $275,000 grant to
Hopkins from the Fund for the
Advancement of Education, is
looking for ways to encourage
outstanding college graduates to
prepare themselves for secondary
school teaching. It is administered by the Department of Education at Hopkins.
The general aim of the program, according to Dr. John
Walton, director, is to attract
academically
teaching
into
superior liberal arts college graduates and to give them an opportunity to pursue their academic interests as well as their
for
preparation
professional
teaching.

"Colleges and universities must
plan for expansion even if their
administrations hope to maintain enrollment at their present
level. Tomorrow's college will require more facilities per student
in addition to more facilities for
students," explained Gavin A.
Pitt, Vice President of the Johns
Hopkins University, speaking before a meeting of the Norwich
Society at the Yale Club in New
York City.
The increasing complexity of
education, especially in the
sciences, makes it necessary for
a school to build new laboratory
buildings and new libraries in
order to provide education equivalent to today's standards for
the same number of stutents.
Needs Increasing
"Should a university wish to
expand its enrollment," Mr. Pitt
pointed out, "the problem is only
intensified. The present boy in
college has at his disposal twice
as many books in the university
library as did his father, and
four times as many as did his
grandfather.
"In the science laboratory, the
apparatus of modern physics re-

quires a tremendous capital investment when compared to the
traditional table-top experimental materials of classical physics."
Mr. Pitt went on to explain
that Johns Hopkins, in the midst
of a $76,380,000 development
program, needs these funds to
continue to provide quality education for a limited number of
students. "Johns Hopkins has no
plans for large-scale expansion."
Mr. Pitt said; "but it will continue its emphasis on scholarship
and research."
Double Trouble
"Should Hopkins decide to
double its enrollment, its need
for capital funds would quadruple. Modern higher education
is becoming more expensive
•
every year," Mr. Pitt said.
The address was presented to
one hundred members of the
Norwich Society of New York at
their annual meeting. The Norwich Society is a group of sons
of Norwich, Connecticut, who
meet annually to hear a talk on
current problems. Mr. Pitt is a
native of Norwich and attended
Norwich Free Academy.

Concerts
Two concerts Sunday afternoon will close the big weekend:
the annual session in the "Jazz
at Homewood" series from 3 to 5
and the annual JHU Orchestra
concert at 4 p.m. in Shriver.
The jazz concert will feature
the Spruce Street Stompers, a
Dixieland group from the University of Pennsylvania, announced Os Steinwald. A collection will be taken up at the
concert for the lacrosse trip.
Mr. Steinwald announced that
he expects the largest Homecoming turnout ever this weekend.
"The combination of recent
classes' reunions, other classes
returning after previous reunions and the Maryland game
should result in the larga.st attendance we've ever had at a
Homecoming."

THE GREAT CAP AND GOWN
CONTROVERSY
It will soon be cap and gown time again,so let Us, without delay,
take up the vexing question: which side of the cap should the
tassel hang on?
For many years the practice was to hang the tassel over the
front of the cap. This practice was abandoned in 1948 when the
entire graduating class of Northwestern University, blinded by
tassels hanging in their eyes, made a wrong turn during commencement exercises and ended up at the Great Lakes Naval
Training Center where, all unwitting, they were inducted into
the submarine service for five-year hitches.

There is a growing body of opinion which bolds that the
tassel should be worn on the same side you keep your Marlboro
Cigarettes on. Thus a quick glance will show you where your
Marlboros are and save much time and fumbling.
This makes a good deal of sense becau§e when one wants a
Marlboro, one wants one with a minimum of delay. One does
not relish being kept, even for a second,from the heaps of joy,
the barrels of pleasure, the scads of content,.the loads of glee,
the lumps of ecstasy, that one gets from that filter, that flavor,
that flip-top box.
There is another group, small but vocal, which insists the
tassel should bang over the back of the cap. The tassel, they say,
is a symbol like the bullfighter's pigtail, signifying honor and
courage.
They are wrong. Bullfighters wear pigtails for only one
reason: to keep the backs of their necks warm. Do you have any
idea what a draft a bull makes when he rushes past you? A
plenty big anc, you may be sure.
In fact, upper respiratory infections, contracted in the wake
of passing bulls, is the largest single cause of bull-ring fatalities.
I have this interesting statistic from the Bullfighters Mutual
Insurance Company of Hartford, Connecticut. Incidentally,
• Hartford, the insurance capital of America, is a delightful city
and well worth a visit if you are ever in New England, as northeastern United States is laughingly called. Try to make your
visit in spring when the actuaries are in bloom.
But I digress. We were talking about what side to wear the
tassel on. An ingenious solution to this problem was proposed

ABOVE—Dr. Jerzy L. Nowinski, noted authority on elasticity,
only recently sought refuge in
the United States from behind
the Iron Curtain. The Polishborn scientist came to the U. S.
with a scientific mission. Upon
hearing that his wife and daughter had reached England safely,
he immediately asked for asylum
here. Hopkins invited him to
give a series of lectures on topics
in his field, and were able to
place him on the faculty, much
to the joy and appreciation of
Dr. Nowinski. Determined to
settle as quickly as possible into
the way of life he is desirous
of calling his own, he has made
it his business to learn and acquire as many American customs and habits as possible.

spinner, one little lady seems cheekishly happy with the evening,
as another (lower left) stares in consternation at the proceedings.

Play About Illicit Love, Music
Closes 'Good'Playshop Season
By PAUL BERMAN
The Concert, by Hermann
Bahr, twentieth century modern
Austrian playwright, is this
season's final Playshop offering.
Having first appeared in 1909,
The Concert concerns a Viennese
pianist and music teacher, Gustave Hein, who goes away periodically to a mountain cabin
where he carries on affairs with
his adoring female pupils. These
are his non-musical "concerts".
Hein's wife and the husband of
the sweet young girl who is the
object of Hein's latest "concert",
conspire to confront their respective mates in the mountain
cabin.
'Just a Fling'
The result of this meeting leads
the play to its logical conclusion.
Hein realizes that this is just
a middle-aged "fling" that he's
having, and that he really appreciates his wife, the woman who
-cooks, cleans, and keeps house
for him. The object of his fleeting affections and her husband
get back together again, too,
although by the play's end, author Bahr leaves us wondering
whether his pianist isn't about

to go off again, merely through
force-of-habit, on another "concert".
A Little Long
Although we greatly admire
the Playshop's purist policy of
presenting distinguished plays in
their entirety, we feel that this
one. was, perhaps, a trifle too
long. The last act, which plays
for one hour, could have stood a
few discriminatory cuts by the
director. Certain expository reiterations could well have been
omitted without any dire'effects.
The members of the fine cast
of The Concert truly deserve a
croix de guerre for having memorized so many pages of dialogue
which, with the exception of a
jerky-starting, cue-missing first
part of the first act, they rendered flawlessly.
Talk, Talk, Talk
Betty Jane Bupp, Virginia
Jones, Matina Psoras, Josephine
Shyers, Jane DeSoto and Florence Joska, as the idol-worshipping pupil of pianist Hein, did
as they were told and babbled
incessantly all through their
brief appearance in the first act.
However, we found this cacophony of sound thoroughly un-

bearable, and felt that it would
be a millenium before these delightful ladies finally took their
leave.
Walter Koehler, as Hein, was
excellent. He was everything the
role of the middle-aged Lothario
demanded of him, and more.
Edythe Dorsey, as his wife Marie,
was an attractive, regal figure,
while at the same time an understanding, clever wife.
Ralph
Piersanti as Frank Jura, husband
of Hein's latest paramour, was
He handled his
outstanding.
highly stylized role deftly and
skillfully.
A 'Charming Beauty'
Betty Mariner Shaffer, as Mr.
Piersanti's erring wife, was a
charming coquette whose beauty
made it easily understandable to
see why other men would be
attracted to her. Ivan Trosch's
bucolic bumpkinry was a pure
delight, although Virginia Dieffenbach's Baltimorese was a bit
anachronistic for an Austrian
country wife.
Bill Winchester's sets and the
costumes by A. T. Jones and Sons
all added to the high quality of
this production. The play was
Harwood
Alice
by
directed
Houstle.

Jays Clash With 'Rough' Maryland
'Evenly Matched' Enemies
To Contend For Top Title

JAY'S
NEST
The complacent attitude
of the Board of Intramural
Athletics was blamed for
the pathetic situation of the
Intramural program by this
column in last week's NewsLetter.
In reply to this accusation, members of the Board
stated that the reason they
have not stimulated any
interest in intramurals is
that the Athletic Department does not have the facilities available for expansion of the intramural program. They argued that
playing fields and equipment
to even carry out the existing program are lacking.
The Johns Hopkins University Circular states, "The
intramural program is designed to care for all students who are not members
of intercollegiate squads.
Interest and participation
are encouraged in as many
activities as possible."
Participation!
"We're primarily interested in participation," commented Athletic Director
Marshall S. Turner, Jr.,
earlier this year.
. The emphasis is on wide
participation, and yet when
there is participation, Hopkins' facilities prove to be
inadequate.
However, the intramural
Program is not all that is
suffering from the Athletic
Department's apparent lack
of finances.
When the Athletic Director claims that there is
equal emphasis on all sports,
We cannot help but wonder
What the lacrosse team's reaction would be to the idea
of buying their own equipment.
(Continued on page 14)

Notices
All students planning to attend tomorrow's lacrosse game
are reminded that the student
identification card is required
for admission to Homewood
Field.
The final meeting of the
Class of 1955 will be held at
noon today in Levering Hall.
At the meeting the permanent officers of the class will
be nominated and elected.
Also the final June Week and
Jazz Concert plans will be
made. The singing octet from
Goucher, the "Reverend's
Rebels," will entertain the
class.
The date for fall registration is Monday, September 22.
All undergraduates are required to appear on that day.
Students who do not plan to
return to the university should
notify the Registrar's Office
as soon as possible.

Mike Lukens was elected president of the YMCA Student
Cabinet in an election held last
week. Chosen vice-president and
secretary, respectively, were Boland McCamy and Harry Lambright. Also to serve as elected
members of the cabinet next year
will be Turpin Rose and Erhard
Joeres.
In accordance with the YMCA
Constitution, the entire membership of the 'Y' elects five undergraduates to serve on its cabinet. These five choose from
among themselves a president,
and secretary; and appoint six
additional Cabinet members.
Mike Lukens, in a statement
released to the News-Letter,
stated: "We are looking forward
to a great year at Levering Hall.
With the help and support of a
strong cabinet, we have many
plans to expand into new areas
and strengthen existing areas,
all geared to the interests and
services of the • campus and the
community.
"We
feel
confident that
through the breadth and depth
of our program next year, we will
have something of value to all
and can make a very real contribution to the campus again
this coming year."

A total of 84 Reserve Officer
Training Corps cadets at the
Johns Hopkins shared in 49
awards presented for outstanding service last Monday in the
annual ceremonies at Homewood
Field.
,
Two Hopkins cadets already
have been named recipients of
national awards presented by the
Society of American Military Engineers. They are Cadet Gilbert
F. Decker and John P. McNealey.
Only ten awards are presented
throughout the nation in each
of the two categories, senior and
junior students.
Other major awards included
the presentation of the Baltimore Sunpapers Medal to George
Schwartz, the Superior Cadet
Ribbon (MS IV) to Clifford
Harding, (MS III) to John St.
Clair, (MS II) to William
Sweeney, and (MS I) to Donald
R. Lampe. The medal for the
best-drilled sophomore went to
Philip Medenbach while that
for best-drilled freshman was
awarded to William Kirwan.
John Gilbert was honored as

the commanding officer of the
best-drilled company, Company
"A". Joseph Fetsch was the leader of the best platoon.
Guests at the ceremonies included Colonel Joseph Golden,
Deputy Commander, XXI U.S.
Army Corps (Reserve); Stewart
P. Macauley, Provost of Hopkins; Colonel John Keefe, Sector
Commander. Maryland-District
of Columbia Sector, X.XI U.S.
Army Corps (Reserve), Dr. G.
Wilson Shaffer, Dean of the
Homewood Schools.
Also Colonel Ronald McGrayne of the Military Order of
World Wars; Dr. Robert H. Roy,
Dean of Engineering at Hopkins, and others.

Mitchell Captures
•.
Two Prize Photos
Bruce Mitchell captured both
first and third place in the black
and white division of the
Camera Club's annual Photography contest held May 6th in
the Sherwood Room of Levering
Hall.
Second place in the black and
white division went to Walt
Suter. In the color transparency
division graduate students ran
away with it. John Gallagher
(Physics) took first place, and
Ron Straka (Astrophysics) took
second and third.
Mrs. Walter Suter, in recognition of.her constant service to
the Club was made an honorary
member by unanimous vote.
"A selection of the entries in
both categories will be on display
in Levering Hall through Monday, May 19, 1958," stated Walt
Johnson, newly elected secretary.
In the Camera Club's annual
elections, Bruce Mitchell was
made President; Vice-President,
Stanley Kiosk; Secretary, Walt
Johnson; Treasurer, Watson
Dougherty. .

Theme Of Floats

"Hopkins goes to England"
will be the theme of the annual
Homecoming Float Parade sponsored by the Johns Hopkins
held
be
Club, to
Booster
before the Maryland-Hopkins
lacrosse game, Saturday, May 17,
1958.
"So far, ten fraternities have
indicated, that they will take
part in the parade, and we expect more," said Dick Weigmann,
Chairman of the Booster Club's
Float Committee.
The parade is open to all
Hopkins organizations as well as
social fraternities. It is being
held in order to increase school
spirit, stated a letter recently
distributed by the Booster Club.
The winning organization is
to gain possession of the Booster
Club trophy for a year, and permanent possession of a smaller
trophy. The Queen of the organization is to be proclaimed
"Queen of Homecoming." The
Queen will also be presented at
the H-Club's Starlighter Dance
tomorrow evening.
The tentative route for the
parade shows it forming at San
Martin Drive, proceeding east on
University Parkway, and entering the campus through the
West Gate.

For 'Y' Talk
"Drinking in College" will be
the topic of a lecture by Dr.
Seldon D. Bacon, Yale University
professor of Sociology, to be presented at a student assembly in
Shriver Hall, Friday, May 23,
at 10 a.m.
Dr. Bacon, who is also the
Director of the Yale Center of
Alcoholic Studies, is recognized
as a world leading authority on
alcohol and the social problems
it presents. In collaboration with
Dr. Robert Straus, also a Yale
sociologist, he wrote Drinking
in College, a survey of the customs and attitudes toward alcohol of men and women in 27
American colleges.
The program is sponsored by
the Levering Hall Y.M.C.A. and
the Student Council. All students
are invited to attend the program.

By DAVE BAKER
Copy Editor
Over one thousand Hopkins alumni and about ten University
of Maryland lacrosse players will arrive tumultuously on campus
today and tomorrow as the annual Hopkins Alumni Homecoming
Weekend gets under way.
The first group will take part in a series of luncheons, banquets, class reunions and discussion groups; the Maryland contingent will meet with the Jay lacrossemen which could decide
the National Lacrosse Championship.
Activities begin tonight, according to Mr. Osmar P. Steinwald,
Director of Alumni Relations, with the Johns Hopkins Engineers'
annual dinner and assembly beginning at 6 p.m. in the Aeronautics
Building. Guest Speaker Dr. John Strong will deliver an address
on "Getting Ready for Mars." Also, the Classes of 1918 and 1933
will hold reunion dinners this evening.
The traditional Blue Jay, beer, music and cheers will spark
a pep rally at 7 this evening in front of the Old Dorm. Students
are encouraged, says an announcement, to come and "make your
own pep speeches." The lacrosse team and coaches will also be
present.
Saturday's scheduled events are headed by a tour of the
campus in the morning to acquaint visiting alumni with recent
facelifting at Homewood.
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, Hopkins University President, is to
chair the second annual symposium feating seven faculty members,
from 10:30 to 12 noon Saturday in Shriver Hall. This year's topic
is "An Intimate Report on New Developments at Johns Hopkins."
Dr. Donald H. Andrews, Provost P. Stewart Macaulay, Dr. William
D. McElroy, Dean Richard A. Mumma, Dean Robert H. Roy, Dean
Thomas B. Turner, and 41)r. John Walton will participate.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 16, 1958

Long Saturates TV Game, Parade, Dance, Drinks
With Political Ads Spark Homecoming Weekend
(Continued from Page 1)
In an attempt to curry the
favor of as many Maryland Democrats as possible before the
Primary election date, Tuesday,
May 20, Dr. Clarence D. Long
launched a saturation campaign
of the various television stations
in Maryland.
This TV campaign began about
two weeks ago and will reach its
climax on Monday, the day before the. primary, when Dr. Long
will have six brief filmed messages transmitted via Baltimore
television channels. In addition
to this Monday splurge, the Hopkins economics professor will be
seen four times today and tomorrow and will make two appearances on Sunday.
Dr. Long also appears daily on
a one minute spot over the Salisbury, Maryland, UHF channel.
These spot telecasts are composed of filmed sequences of
Dr. Long meeting the voters in
a drug store and in the Mondawmin Shopping Center.
Commenting upon the statement of Dean Acheson, former
U. S. Secretary of State, that
Maryland needs a "responsible
boss", Dr. Long said, "The remedy for the problems of democracy can be found through democracy. What is wrong with
Maryland politics is 'bossism' in
any way. This can be seen in
the counties which are devoid

Varsity Lacrosse Team Set
For Journey To England
By JOEL GORDEN
Coach Robert Scott, Trainer
James Benson and a squad of
twenty-three players will leave
Baltimore June 16 for Montreal
for the first leg of their scheduled trip to England to play a
series of contests against English collegiate and club lacrosse
teams.
Visiting England at the invitation of the English Lacrosse
Union, the team will spend about
two months abroad. The first
game will be played against
Cambridge, where they will stay
two days. They will return to
Manchester July 12, where they
will play a series of tilts against
club teams.
From July 12-16 the squad
will take a break. They will take
a sight-seeing tour of Scotland.
On the 21st the Jays will return
to England to play Kenton Lacrosse Club. As a follow-up the
stickmen will meet the South of
England All-Star Lacrosse Club.

Returned To JHTJ
In 1948 Professor Singleton
joined,the faculty of Harvard
University as professor of Romance Languages. He returned
to Johns Hopkins last September
as professor of humanistic studies, making use of his broad
knowledge of philosophy, arts and

The scholar is currently working on a three-volume commentary on Dante's Divine Comedy
which is an outgrowth of his
definitive books on Italian literature.
Born In Oklahoma
Born in McCloud, Oklahoma,
Dr. Singleton received his A.B.
degree in 1931 at the University
of Missouri and his Ph.D. in
1936 from the University of California.
From 1934 to 1936 he was an
exchange Fellow in Italy. After
his return to this country he
taught for a year each at the
University of California and the

Chemical Concern
Grants Thousands
For Cancer Work
A $5,000 grant has been made
to the Division of Clinical Pharmacology of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital by the American Cyanamid Company.
The award is designed to promote the evaluation of anticancer drugs and compounds affecting the central nervous system.
Dr. Louis Lasagna of the Hopkins, in accepting the award
from Dr. Benjamin Carey, Medical Director of Lederle Laboratories of American Cyanamid,
said that the work of his group
falls into two main categories.
These are the evaluation of
drugs as sedatives, hypnotics and
tranquillizers, and the testing of
drugs for cancer chemotherapy.
The work is being conducted at
the Hopkins Hospital and at state
institutions.
The American Cyanamid grant
is part of a $1,300,000 award
program designed to spur basic
scientific and medical research.

Form Dramatic Commission For E. E. Honor. Society
The Johns Hopkins Electrical
Engineering Honor Society received national recognition last
Friday when it was installed as
the Gamma Upsilon Chapter of
the National Eta Kappa Nu Association.

an

week.

dramatic groups from Mt. St.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 16, 1958

Hopkins To Sponsor Pitt Cites Expanding Needs
Of Education In Address
Fifth-Year Training
Six Baltimore students are
among 45 chosen by The Johns
Hopkins University to take part
in a fifth-year tdacher training
program which begins in June, it
by Dr.
was announced today7
John Walton, chairman of the
Department of Education.
The students were chosen from
200 applicants representing colleges and universities throughout the nation and "comprise a
superior group," according to
University officials.
The Baltimore residents are:
Miss Judith Ann Goldberg,from
Goucher College whose field is
social studies; Anna F. Kovasznay, a graduate of Royal Hungarian Peter Pazmany University in Budapest, who will major
in languages; Joseph A. M. Lettre, Pikesville, a student at the
University of Maryland majoring in social studies; Thor S.
Ramsland, majoring in social
studies at Johns Hopkins; Robert
C. Smoot III, a science student
from The Pennsylvania State
University; and Miss Ruth Dolores Townsend, a Wilson College English major.

The Johns Hopkins Program
begins in June with the summer
session and continues through
the full academic year. Each person in the program will also be
hired by a board of education
to teach one semester in a public
or private school in the greater
Baltimore area. The second
semester is to be spent in academic work at the graduate level
on the Homewood Campus.
The program, made possible a
year ago by a $275,000 grant to
Hopkins from the Fund for the
Advancement of Education, is
looking for ways to encourage
outstanding college graduates to
prepare themselves for secondary
school teaching. It is administered by the Department of Education at Hopkins.
The general aim of the program, according to Dr. John
Walton, director, is to attract
academically
teaching
into
superior liberal arts college graduates and to give them an opportunity to pursue their academic interests as well as their
for
preparation
professional
teaching.

"Colleges and universities must
plan for expansion even if their
administrations hope to maintain enrollment at their present
level. Tomorrow's college will require more facilities per student
in addition to more facilities for
students," explained Gavin A.
Pitt, Vice President of the Johns
Hopkins University, speaking before a meeting of the Norwich
Society at the Yale Club in New
York City.
The increasing complexity of
education, especially in the
sciences, makes it necessary for
a school to build new laboratory
buildings and new libraries in
order to provide education equivalent to today's standards for
the same number of stutents.
Needs Increasing
"Should a university wish to
expand its enrollment," Mr. Pitt
pointed out, "the problem is only
intensified. The present boy in
college has at his disposal twice
as many books in the university
library as did his father, and
four times as many as did his
grandfather.
"In the science laboratory, the
apparatus of modern physics re-

quires a tremendous capital investment when compared to the
traditional table-top experimental materials of classical physics."
Mr. Pitt went on to explain
that Johns Hopkins, in the midst
of a $76,380,000 development
program, needs these funds to
continue to provide quality education for a limited number of
students. "Johns Hopkins has no
plans for large-scale expansion."
Mr. Pitt said; "but it will continue its emphasis on scholarship
and research."
Double Trouble
"Should Hopkins decide to
double its enrollment, its need
for capital funds would quadruple. Modern higher education
is becoming more expensive
•
every year," Mr. Pitt said.
The address was presented to
one hundred members of the
Norwich Society of New York at
their annual meeting. The Norwich Society is a group of sons
of Norwich, Connecticut, who
meet annually to hear a talk on
current problems. Mr. Pitt is a
native of Norwich and attended
Norwich Free Academy.

Concerts
Two concerts Sunday afternoon will close the big weekend:
the annual session in the "Jazz
at Homewood" series from 3 to 5
and the annual JHU Orchestra
concert at 4 p.m. in Shriver.
The jazz concert will feature
the Spruce Street Stompers, a
Dixieland group from the University of Pennsylvania, announced Os Steinwald. A collection will be taken up at the
concert for the lacrosse trip.
Mr. Steinwald announced that
he expects the largest Homecoming turnout ever this weekend.
"The combination of recent
classes' reunions, other classes
returning after previous reunions and the Maryland game
should result in the larga.st attendance we've ever had at a
Homecoming."

THE GREAT CAP AND GOWN
CONTROVERSY
It will soon be cap and gown time again,so let Us, without delay,
take up the vexing question: which side of the cap should the
tassel hang on?
For many years the practice was to hang the tassel over the
front of the cap. This practice was abandoned in 1948 when the
entire graduating class of Northwestern University, blinded by
tassels hanging in their eyes, made a wrong turn during commencement exercises and ended up at the Great Lakes Naval
Training Center where, all unwitting, they were inducted into
the submarine service for five-year hitches.

There is a growing body of opinion which bolds that the
tassel should be worn on the same side you keep your Marlboro
Cigarettes on. Thus a quick glance will show you where your
Marlboros are and save much time and fumbling.
This makes a good deal of sense becau§e when one wants a
Marlboro, one wants one with a minimum of delay. One does
not relish being kept, even for a second,from the heaps of joy,
the barrels of pleasure, the scads of content,.the loads of glee,
the lumps of ecstasy, that one gets from that filter, that flavor,
that flip-top box.
There is another group, small but vocal, which insists the
tassel should bang over the back of the cap. The tassel, they say,
is a symbol like the bullfighter's pigtail, signifying honor and
courage.
They are wrong. Bullfighters wear pigtails for only one
reason: to keep the backs of their necks warm. Do you have any
idea what a draft a bull makes when he rushes past you? A
plenty big anc, you may be sure.
In fact, upper respiratory infections, contracted in the wake
of passing bulls, is the largest single cause of bull-ring fatalities.
I have this interesting statistic from the Bullfighters Mutual
Insurance Company of Hartford, Connecticut. Incidentally,
• Hartford, the insurance capital of America, is a delightful city
and well worth a visit if you are ever in New England, as northeastern United States is laughingly called. Try to make your
visit in spring when the actuaries are in bloom.
But I digress. We were talking about what side to wear the
tassel on. An ingenious solution to this problem was proposed

ABOVE—Dr. Jerzy L. Nowinski, noted authority on elasticity,
only recently sought refuge in
the United States from behind
the Iron Curtain. The Polishborn scientist came to the U. S.
with a scientific mission. Upon
hearing that his wife and daughter had reached England safely,
he immediately asked for asylum
here. Hopkins invited him to
give a series of lectures on topics
in his field, and were able to
place him on the faculty, much
to the joy and appreciation of
Dr. Nowinski. Determined to
settle as quickly as possible into
the way of life he is desirous
of calling his own, he has made
it his business to learn and acquire as many American customs and habits as possible.

Play About Illicit Love, Music
Closes 'Good'Playshop Season
By PAUL BERMAN
The Concert, by Hermann
Bahr, twentieth century modern
Austrian playwright, is this
season's final Playshop offering.
Having first appeared in 1909,
The Concert concerns a Viennese
pianist and music teacher, Gustave Hein, who goes away periodically to a mountain cabin
where he carries on affairs with
his adoring female pupils. These
are his non-musical "concerts".
Hein's wife and the husband of
the sweet young girl who is the
object of Hein's latest "concert",
conspire to confront their respective mates in the mountain
cabin.
'Just a Fling'
The result of this meeting leads
the play to its logical conclusion.
Hein realizes that this is just
a middle-aged "fling" that he's
having, and that he really appreciates his wife, the woman who
-cooks, cleans, and keeps house
for him. The object of his fleeting affections and her husband
get back together again, too,
although by the play's end, author Bahr leaves us wondering
whether his pianist isn't about

to go off again, merely through
force-of-habit, on another "concert".
A Little Long
Although we greatly admire
the Playshop's purist policy of
presenting distinguished plays in
their entirety, we feel that this
one. was, perhaps, a trifle too
long. The last act, which plays
for one hour, could have stood a
few discriminatory cuts by the
director. Certain expository reiterations could well have been
omitted without any dire'effects.
The members of the fine cast
of The Concert truly deserve a
croix de guerre for having memorized so many pages of dialogue
which, with the exception of a
jerky-starting, cue-missing first
part of the first act, they rendered flawlessly.
Talk, Talk, Talk
Betty Jane Bupp, Virginia
Jones, Matina Psoras, Josephine
Shyers, Jane DeSoto and Florence Joska, as the idol-worshipping pupil of pianist Hein, did
as they were told and babbled
incessantly all through their
brief appearance in the first act.
However, we found this cacophony of sound thoroughly un-

bearable, and felt that it would
be a millenium before these delightful ladies finally took their
leave.
Walter Koehler, as Hein, was
excellent. He was everything the
role of the middle-aged Lothario
demanded of him, and more.
Edythe Dorsey, as his wife Marie,
was an attractive, regal figure,
while at the same time an understanding, clever wife.
Ralph
Piersanti as Frank Jura, husband
of Hein's latest paramour, was
He handled his
outstanding.
highly stylized role deftly and
skillfully.
A 'Charming Beauty'
Betty Mariner Shaffer, as Mr.
Piersanti's erring wife, was a
charming coquette whose beauty
made it easily understandable to
see why other men would be
attracted to her. Ivan Trosch's
bucolic bumpkinry was a pure
delight, although Virginia Dieffenbach's Baltimorese was a bit
anachronistic for an Austrian
country wife.
Bill Winchester's sets and the
costumes by A. T. Jones and Sons
all added to the high quality of
this production. The play was

Jays Clash With 'Rough' Maryland
'Evenly Matched' Enemies
To Contend For Top Title

JAY'S
NEST
The complacent attitude
of the Board of Intramural
Athletics was blamed for
the pathetic situation of the
Intramural program by this
column in last week's NewsLetter.
In reply to this accusation, members of the Board
stated that the reason they
have not stimulated any
interest in intramurals is
that the Athletic Department does not have the facilities available for expansion of the intramural program. They argued that
playing fields and equipment
to even carry out the existing program are lacking.
The Johns Hopkins University Circular states, "The
intramural program is designed to care for all students who are not members
of intercollegiate squads.
Interest and participation
are encouraged in as many
activities as possible."
Participation!
"We're primarily interested in participation," commented Athletic Director
Marshall S. Turner, Jr.,
earlier this year.
. The emphasis is on wide
participation, and yet when
there is participation, Hopkins' facilities prove to be
inadequate.
However, the intramural
Program is not all that is
suffering from the Athletic
Department's apparent lack
of finances.
When the Athletic Director claims that there is
equal emphasis on all sports,
We cannot help but wonder
What the lacrosse team's reaction would be to the idea
of buying their own equipment.
(Continued on page 14)

Notices
All students planning to attend tomorrow's lacrosse game
are reminded that the student
identification card is required
for admission to Homewood
Field.
The final meeting of the
Class of 1955 will be held at
noon today in Levering Hall.
At the meeting the permanent officers of the class will
be nominated and elected.
Also the final June Week and
Jazz Concert plans will be
made. The singing octet from
Goucher, the "Reverend's
Rebels," will entertain the
class.
The date for fall registration is Monday, September 22.
All undergraduates are required to appear on that day.
Students who do not plan to
return to the university should
notify the Registrar's Office
as soon as possible.

Mike Lukens was elected president of the YMCA Student
Cabinet in an election held last
week. Chosen vice-president and
secretary, respectively, were Boland McCamy and Harry Lambright. Also to serve as elected
members of the cabinet next year
will be Turpin Rose and Erhard
Joeres.
In accordance with the YMCA
Constitution, the entire membership of the 'Y' elects five undergraduates to serve on its cabinet. These five choose from
among themselves a president,
and secretary; and appoint six
additional Cabinet members.
Mike Lukens, in a statement
released to the News-Letter,
stated: "We are looking forward
to a great year at Levering Hall.
With the help and support of a
strong cabinet, we have many
plans to expand into new areas
and strengthen existing areas,
all geared to the interests and
services of the • campus and the
community.
"We
feel
confident that
through the breadth and depth
of our program next year, we will
have something of value to all
and can make a very real contribution to the campus again
this coming year."

A total of 84 Reserve Officer
Training Corps cadets at the
Johns Hopkins shared in 49
awards presented for outstanding service last Monday in the
annual ceremonies at Homewood
Field.
,
Two Hopkins cadets already
have been named recipients of
national awards presented by the
Society of American Military Engineers. They are Cadet Gilbert
F. Decker and John P. McNealey.
Only ten awards are presented
throughout the nation in each
of the two categories, senior and
junior students.
Other major awards included
the presentation of the Baltimore Sunpapers Medal to George
Schwartz, the Superior Cadet
Ribbon (MS IV) to Clifford
Harding, (MS III) to John St.
Clair, (MS II) to William
Sweeney, and (MS I) to Donald
R. Lampe. The medal for the
best-drilled sophomore went to
Philip Medenbach while that
for best-drilled freshman was
awarded to William Kirwan.
John Gilbert was honored as

the commanding officer of the
best-drilled company, Company
"A". Joseph Fetsch was the leader of the best platoon.
Guests at the ceremonies included Colonel Joseph Golden,
Deputy Commander, XXI U.S.
Army Corps (Reserve); Stewart
P. Macauley, Provost of Hopkins; Colonel John Keefe, Sector
Commander. Maryland-District
of Columbia Sector, X.XI U.S.
Army Corps (Reserve), Dr. G.
Wilson Shaffer, Dean of the
Homewood Schools.
Also Colonel Ronald McGrayne of the Military Order of
World Wars; Dr. Robert H. Roy,
Dean of Engineering at Hopkins, and others.

Mitchell Captures
•.
Two Prize Photos
Bruce Mitchell captured both
first and third place in the black
and white division of the
Camera Club's annual Photography contest held May 6th in
the Sherwood Room of Levering
Hall.
Second place in the black and
white division went to Walt
Suter. In the color transparency
division graduate students ran
away with it. John Gallagher
(Physics) took first place, and
Ron Straka (Astrophysics) took
second and third.
Mrs. Walter Suter, in recognition of.her constant service to
the Club was made an honorary
member by unanimous vote.
"A selection of the entries in
both categories will be on display
in Levering Hall through Monday, May 19, 1958," stated Walt
Johnson, newly elected secretary.
In the Camera Club's annual
elections, Bruce Mitchell was
made President; Vice-President,
Stanley Kiosk; Secretary, Walt
Johnson; Treasurer, Watson
Dougherty. .

Boosters Choose
Theme Of Floats

"Hopkins goes to England"
will be the theme of the annual
Homecoming Float Parade sponsored by the Johns Hopkins
held
be
Club, to
Booster
before the Maryland-Hopkins
lacrosse game, Saturday, May 17,
1958.
"So far, ten fraternities have
indicated, that they will take
part in the parade, and we expect more," said Dick Weigmann,
Chairman of the Booster Club's
Float Committee.
The parade is open to all
Hopkins organizations as well as
social fraternities. It is being
held in order to increase school
spirit, stated a letter recently
distributed by the Booster Club.
The winning organization is
to gain possession of the Booster
Club trophy for a year, and permanent possession of a smaller
trophy. The Queen of the organization is to be proclaimed
"Queen of Homecoming." The
Queen will also be presented at
the H-Club's Starlighter Dance
tomorrow evening.
The tentative route for the
parade shows it forming at San
Martin Drive, proceeding east on
University Parkway, and entering the campus through the
West Gate.

For 'Y' Talk
"Drinking in College" will be
the topic of a lecture by Dr.
Seldon D. Bacon, Yale University
professor of Sociology, to be presented at a student assembly in
Shriver Hall, Friday, May 23,
at 10 a.m.
Dr. Bacon, who is also the
Director of the Yale Center of
Alcoholic Studies, is recognized
as a world leading authority on
alcohol and the social problems
it presents. In collaboration with
Dr. Robert Straus, also a Yale
sociologist, he wrote Drinking
in College, a survey of the customs and attitudes toward alcohol of men and women in 27
American colleges.
The program is sponsored by
the Levering Hall Y.M.C.A. and
the Student Council. All students
are invited to attend the program.
